Links: [{"title":"GitHub - craigtaub/snapandcompare: Screenshot comparison tool used for CSS Visual Regression Testing.","url":"https://github.com/craigtaub/snapandcompare"},{"title":"20 Best Visual Regression Testing Tool Reviewed in 2026","url":"https://thectoclub.com/tools/best-visual-regression-testing-tools/"},{"title":"Top 18 Visual Testing Tools for Testers (2026 Guide)","url":"https://testguild.com/visual-validation-tools/"},{"title":"Survey of screenshot-based CSS testing tools · GitHub","url":"https://gist.github.com/cvrebert/adf91e429906a4d746cd"},{"title":"How Visual Diff Algorithm Improves Visual Testing | BrowserStack","url":"https://www.browserstack.com/guide/visual-diff-algorithm-to-improve-visual-testing"},{"title":"Image comparison tools for automated screenshot testing","url":"https://www.screenster.io/image-comparison-tool/"},{"title":"19 Best Visual Testing Tools for 2026 | LambdaTest","url":"https://www.lambdatest.com/blog/visual-testing-tools/"},{"title":"Visual Regression Testing For Drupal And WordPress","url":"https://diffy.website/"},{"title":"Top 7 Visual Testing Tools for 2026 - testRigor AI-Based Automated Testing Tool","url":"https://testrigor.com/blog/visual-testing-tools/"},{"title":"Visual Testing using Screenshot Comparison — Ghost Inspector","url":"https://docs.ghostinspector.com/comparing-screenshots/"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of CSS visual diff tools and automated screenshot comparison solutions for 2026:

## Key Visual Diff Tools and Platforms

Visual regression testing tools are software solutions that automatically detect unintended changes in a web application's user interface by capturing baseline screenshots, comparing them against new builds, and flagging visual discrepancies caused by CSS, layout, or component updates, ensuring design consistency across browsers and devices.

### Popular Solutions

**Modern AI-Driven Platforms:**
- Reflect is a no-code test automation platform built for fast, AI-driven visual regression testing that uses natural language prompts and generative AI to turn instructions into complete tests instead of relying on brittle CSS selectors or manual scripting.

- LambdaTest SmartUI automates visual regression testing by comparing captured UI screenshots across browsers and devices, detecting pixel-level differences, layout shifts, and styling inconsistencies.

**Open-Source Tools:**
- SnapAndCompare is an easy to use screenshot comparison tool used for CSS Visual Regression Testing built using NodeJS.

- BackstopJS automates visual regression testing of responsive web UI by comparing DOM screenshots over time.

- PhantomCSS is a visual regression testing tool designed for developers and QA teams that captures screenshots and compares them against baseline images to detect visual changes in web applications.

### How Visual Diff Algorithms Work

A Visual Diff Algorithm compares two images, typically a baseline (expected) image and a new (current) image, and identifies unintended UI changes, layout shifts, or regressions in software applications.

### Key Features in 2026

AI-driven comparison filters out dynamic content like timestamps or animations, minimizing false positives and making it easier for teams to detect layout issues and unexpected UI shifts quickly.

Here are the search results for "design to code workflow Figma CLI export 2026":

## Key Findings

**Figma's Official Design-to-Code Solutions:**

Figma Make allows you to generate HTML, CSS, and JavaScript from frames—refine, test, and export without leaving your workflow.

**Code Connect for Component Mapping:**

Code Connect helps you link design components in your Figma libraries to the corresponding code components in your codebase, running entirely inside Figma and connecting directly to GitHub for repository access. There are two ways to connect your code repositories to Figma: Code Connect UI and Code Connect CLI, both contributing to the same MCP infrastructure.

**AI-Powered Export Tools:**

Visual Copilot allows you to paste exported designs into Builder, into your preferred IDE using their VS Code extension, or into a specific codebase via their CLI. The Visual Copilot CLI automatically analyzes your codebase and generates code that matches your existing patterns, components, and styling conventions.

**2026 Trends:**

In 2026, Figma has improved its developer mode, frameworks are now heavily component-driven, and AI speeds up certain dev tasks by up to 50%, with tools claiming to understand layout intent, component patterns, and responsive behavior.

**Design Tokens Export:**

Tools allow exporting tokens from code via CLI for CI/CD, reviews, and version control, built for modern developer workflows.

Based on the search results, here's what I found related to browser DevTools workflow automation, CSS iteration, and Python in 2026:

## Browser Automation Tools for Python

For high-volume Python scraping, Scrapy is recommended, and for teams using languages like Python, Java, or C#, Selenium and Playwright provide multi-language SDKs.

## Python-Based DevTools Automation

Several Python tools leverage the Chrome DevTools Protocol (CDP):

- **Pydoll**: Pydoll connects directly to the Chrome DevTools Protocol (CDP), providing a natively asynchronous, robust, and fully typed architecture designed for modern scraping with an intuitive high-level API.

- **Playwright**: Playwright is a library to automate Chromium, Firefox and WebKit with a single API, available for Node.js, Python, .Net, and Java.

## DevTools Workflow Features

Browser automation tools like Cypress focus on developer-centric experience with real-time reloads as you code and interactive visual debugging directly within the browser's DevTools.

## CSS and Network Control

For CSS iteration workflows, tools like Pydoll provide total network control to intercept and monitor traffic, and allow you to block CSS to dramatically speed up scraping and save bandwidth, or even modify headers for testing.

The 2026 landscape emphasizes tools that combine ease of use with DevTools integration, making workflow automation increasingly accessible for Python developers.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Percy, Chromatic, visual testing, GitHub integration, and CLI information:

## Percy Visual Testing

Percy is a cloud-based platform by BrowserStack for visual testing and review that takes screenshots of your web app, compares them with the baseline, and highlights any visual differences so that your UI does not break visually.

Percy's visual testing capabilities are accessible through various SDKs that integrate with existing testing frameworks, making it versatile for different development environments.

## CLI and GitHub Integration

Percy can be installed via npm using @percy/cli and framework-specific packages like @percy/cypress. Percy requires permission to access GitHub repositories, which can be set up through the integrations tab where you install the GitHub integration and give access to repositories.

Percy updates the status of pull requests both when changes are detected and when changes are approved.

## Percy vs Chromatic Comparison (2025-2026)

Percy's CI-first design and robust cross-browser testing keep it rock solid in staging and production flows. Percy is recommended if your team needs to validate entire pages across browsers and devices with strong CI integration.

Chromatic is a visual testing and component review tool built for Storybook that automatically captures UI snapshots, detects visual regressions, and helps teams review changes before merging.

I've completed the web search for your query: "CSS live editing browser tools hot reload Python Playwright 2026"

Here are the key findings from the search results:

## CSS Live Editing and Hot Reload Tools

Microsoft released a new Visual Studio 2026 Insiders build that brings performance improvements, especially in startup speed and hot-reload. Chrome's DevTools can be used to change HTML and CSS in the browser and see results, and now there are extensions that integrate Chrome and Edge DevTools into Visual Studio so that changes can be saved back into the application.

## Python Playwright Overview

Playwright is a Python library to automate Chromium, Firefox and WebKit browsers with a single API. The library provides capabilities for CSS manipulation and page control, including the ability to add a `<link rel="stylesheet">` tag or a `<style>` tag with CSS content, returning the added tag when the stylesheet's onload fires or when the CSS content was injected.

## Hot Reload Development Challenges

There are ongoing discussions in the Playwright community about hot reload efficiency. Developers have reported that every time code changes are made and a hot reload is expected, Playwright restarts the browser instance and re-executes the entire test workflow from the beginning, which significantly slows down the development cycle.

The search results show integration of browser DevTools with development environments and various Playwright capabilities for CSS handling, though there isn't specific information about a unified hot reload solution for CSS live editing with Playwright in 2026.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Excalidraw, Mermaid diagrams, collaboration, and technical sketches:

## Overview

Excalidraw is a virtual collaborative whiteboard tool that lets you create sketches easily, and it's known for its hand-drawn style, making diagrams feel more approachable and less formal.

## Integration and Conversion

The mermaid-to-excalidraw tool is an open-source tool that allows users to convert Mermaid.js diagrams into Excalidraw format, enabling developers and designers to take structured, code-generated diagrams and make them editable within Excalidraw's flexible, sketch-like canvas.

## Collaboration Benefits

Excalidraw enables you to easily collaborate with others, and since Excalidraw supports collaboration, you can work on converted diagrams with your team in real-time.

## Use Cases

Software development uses include generating architecture diagrams, flowcharts, and process maps programmatically then refining them visually, while education and design thinking also benefit from mixing structured diagrams with freeform sketches.

The search results show that as of 2025-2026, the integration between Mermaid and Excalidraw continues to be a popular workflow for teams looking to combine the structure of text-based diagramming with the creative flexibility of visual sketching tools.

### Current Friction Points

input_full.command:
gh issue comment 209 --body "$(cat <<'EOF'
## Investigation Complete

### Current Friction Points
- **Iteration latency**: CSS changes require full build → screenshot → compare cycle
- **Ambiguous communication**: Text descriptions of visual intent are imprecise
- **No visual reference**: Implementation starts from written requirements, not mockups
- **Post-facto validation**: Screenshot comparison happens after implementation, not before

---

### Tool Categories Evaluated

#### 1. Visual Regression Testing (Best Immediate Fit)

**Percy** (https://github.com/percy):
- Cloud-based visual testing platform by BrowserStack
- CLI via `@percy/cli` npm package
- GitHub integration: Updates PR status automatically
- **Fit**: Could integrate into existing screenshot workflow, provide automated diffs on PRs

**Open-Source Alternatives** (BackstopJS, SnapAndCompare):
- Self-hosted visual regression tools
- **Fit**: Could enhance existing `sbs capture` + `sbs compliance` workflow

#### 2. Design-to-Code Workflows

**Figma Code Connect**:
- Links Figma design components to code via CLI
- GitHub integration for repository access
- **Fit**: Would require design-first workflow (mockups before implementation)
- Figma MCP server available for Claude integration

**Design Tokens Export**:
- Export design tokens (colors, spacing, typography) from Figma
- CLI-friendly, works with version control
- **Fit**: Could solve CSS variable consistency issues (relates to T6 validator)

#### 3. Browser DevTools Automation

**Playwright + CSS Injection**:
- Can inject CSS via `page.add_style_tag()`
- Python-native, already in our stack
- **Fit**: Could enable live CSS iteration without rebuilds
- Challenge: Hot reload is slow (browser restarts on code changes)

#### 4. Diagram-Based Communication

**Excalidraw/Mermaid**:
- Collaborative whiteboard with hand-drawn aesthetic
- Can import from Mermaid diagrams (text → visual)
- **Fit**: Good for wireframes/layout sketches, less for precise CSS

**SVG Wireframes**:
- Generate SVG wireframes from text descriptions
- Lightweight, no external tools needed
- **Fit**: Could work for quick iteration, but low fidelity

---

### Recommendations

#### Tier 1: Implement Now (Low Hanging Fruit)

1. **Enhance existing screenshot workflow with automated diffing**
   - Integrate SnapAndCompare or similar into `sbs capture`
   - Generate visual diffs automatically, not just pass/fail
   - Store diffs in archive alongside screenshots

2. **Add Playwright CSS hot-swapping for rapid iteration**
   - Create dev mode that injects CSS changes without rebuild
   - Use `page.add_style_tag()` to test CSS tweaks live
   - Save successful changes back to source files

3. **SVG wireframe protocol for layout discussions**
   - Establish convention: user provides SVG sketch for complex layouts
   - Can use ChatGPT, Excalidraw, or hand-coded SVG
   - Commit wireframes to repo alongside implementation

#### Tier 2: Evaluate (Medium Investment)

4. **Figma → Design Tokens workflow**
   - Prototype exporting CSS variables from Figma
   - Test if this improves color/spacing consistency (T6 validator)

5. **Percy or open-source visual regression in CI**
   - Add visual regression checks to GitHub Actions
   - Block PRs if visual changes aren't approved

#### Tier 3: Consider Later (High Investment)

6. **Full Figma-first workflow**
   - User creates mockups in Figma before implementation
   - Export via Code Connect or Visual Copilot

---

### Immediate Next Steps

1. Prototype Playwright CSS hot-swap (quick win, uses existing tech stack)
2. Test SnapAndCompare integration (enhance current `sbs capture`)
3. Establish SVG wireframe convention (zero-cost communication improvement)
4. Research Figma MCP integration (explore if Figma MCP fits Claude Code workflow)

---

**Research Sources**: Percy, Chromatic, SnapAndCompare, Figma Code Connect, Playwright Python API, Excalidraw, Mermaid-to-Excalidraw, Chrome DevTools Protocol documentation
EOF
)"

I've completed a web search for your query about static site generators, custom syntax highlighting, and the Lean theorem prover in 2026. Here's a summary of the relevant findings:

## Lean Theorem Prover

Lean is a functional programming language and theorem prover built for formalizing math and for formal verification, but is flexible enough for general coding. In 2021, Lean 4 was released, which was a reimplementation of the Lean theorem prover capable of producing C code which is then compiled, enabling the development of efficient domain-specific automation.

## Syntax Highlighting for Lean

One notable area of development involves syntax highlighting for Lean on different platforms. Eric Wieser created a PR to Linguist for the Lean 4 grammar so that we can have Lean 4 syntax highlighting on GitHub. However, there have been challenges with this integration.

## Static Site Generators

Regarding static site generators with syntax highlighting capabilities, one concrete example is luasmith. Adding new grammars simply required writing some Lua code, using the LPeg library. Luasmith now supports syntax highlighting for ~150 languages, thanks to Scintillua--and it only increased the gzipped download by about 180 KB!

## Recent Lean Community Activity

Lean Together is an annual meeting for users, developers, and fans of the Lean programming language and theorem prover and its library Mathlib maintained by the Lean Community.

The search results show active development in both syntax highlighting capabilities for Lean and innovation in static site generators, though no specific projects directly combining all three elements in 2026 were found.

Based on the search results, here's what I found relevant to your query about documentation frameworks, mathematical proofs, interactive tools, and D3.js:

## D3.js Overview

D3.js (also known as D3, short for Data-Driven Documents) is a JavaScript library for producing dynamic, interactive data visualizations in web browsers. It makes use of Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG), HTML5, and Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) standards.

## Interactive Mathematical Proof Visualization

A particularly relevant finding is **Treehehe**, a specific project that combines the elements you're interested in: The main D3 work is in treehehe/Resources/scripts/d3tree.js. The main goal of the project is to provide a tool for visualizing proof trees and providing a walk-through of the reasoning process. The initial motivation is to help beginners on their journey of understanding logic.

## D3.js Capabilities

D3 facilitates exploration with reusable interactive behaviors, including panning, zooming, brushing, and dragging. This makes it well-suited for interactive documentation of complex concepts like mathematical proofs.

The search results show that D3.js is extensively used for creating interactive visualizations, and there are already examples of its application in mathematical proof visualization, though the specific 2026 developments or frameworks weren't prominently featured in these results.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about custom code highlighting extensibility in Docusaurus, MkDocs, and Sphinx for 2026:

## Docusaurus

Docusaurus picks up syntax highlighting automatically, powered by Prism React Renderer. For custom extensibility:

- You can change the highlighting theme by passing the theme field in prism in your docusaurus.config.js, or write your own theme if not satisfied with the default.
- To add syntax highlighting for languages not yet supported by Prism, you can swizzle prism-include-languages.
- Docusaurus leverages Prism.js under the hood, supporting 300+ languages via proper aliases.

## MkDocs

While MkDocs may not be as extensible as Sphinx, it is an excellent choice for teams looking for a quick, efficient way to publish documentation. If you're considering using Sphinx because you need to generate reference documentation, you should give mkdocstrings a try – an actively maintained and popular framework building on top of MkDocs.

## Sphinx

Sphinx offers robust extensibility through various plugins and themes. Sphinx uses reStructuredText or Markdown as its markup language, supports multiple output formats, extensive cross references, hierarchical structure, code handling, and built-in extensions. Plus, user-contributed extensions make it the documentation system of choice.

For 2026, Docusaurus, Sphinx, and MkDocs are among the most popular documentation tools, each with different strengths in extensibility and code highlighting capabilities.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about these mathematical documentation frameworks:

## PreTeXt

PreTeXt uses LaTeX syntax for authoring mathematical symbols, expressions and equations, supporting the symbols and constructions provided by MathJax, which closely follows the amsmath package. Using PreTeXt as the source, books can be produced in multiple output formats (HTML, PDF, ePUB) and now Braille.

## Quarto

Quarto builds on Pandoc markdown which has excellent support for LaTeX equations and citations, and adds extensions for cross-references, figure panels, callouts, advanced page layout, and more. Quarto supports LaTeX style equation writing, including both inline and display form equations, as well as numbering equations.

Both frameworks are designed to handle mathematical documentation effectively, with PreTeXt being specifically tailored for mathematical textbooks and educational materials, while Quarto is a more general-purpose technical publishing platform that also handles mathematical content well.

## Framework Trends in 2026

## Programmatic Generation and AI Integration

Current capabilities include scaffolding new pages, components, or routes that follow a known pattern in React, Next.js, Vue, Angular, or Svelte, porting components between frameworks when clear examples are provided, and generating tests, types, and basic docs for APIs you've already designed.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Lean 4 documentation, mathlib4, and doc-gen4:

## Documentation Generation

Doc-gen4 is a document generator for Lean 4. After installing Lean 4, mathlib4 can be compiled, and then the doc-gen4 tool can be used to generate documentation in HTML format.

## Static Site Generation

The root of the built docs will be docbuild/.lake/build/doc/index.html. The mathlib4_docs repository is responsible for generating and publishing the mathlib4 docs, and the HTML files can be found in .lake/build/doc.

## Working with mathlib4

When working with mathlib4 specifically, if you depend on mathlib4 run MATHLIB_NO_CACHE_ON_UPDATE=1 lake update doc-gen4 instead to mitigate a small issue in mathlib's caching mechanism.

## Important Note

Due to the "Same Origin Policy", the generated website will be partially broken if you just open the generated html files in your browser. This is an important consideration when working with the locally-generated static sites.

The search results provide technical documentation from the official GitHub repositories and Lean documentation sites, but don't contain information specifically dated to 2026.

I've completed the web search for your query. Here are the key findings:

## Hugo and Content Generation with APIs (2026)

Hugo, a static site generator, pairs effectively with headless CMS platforms to create efficient, scalable technical blogs, particularly in 2026 with advancements in API-driven content management.

### API-Driven Content Integration

Contentful is a leading headless CMS that provides a scalable solution for enterprise-level blogs and content-heavy websites. As of 2026, Contentful's latest stable version is 10.11.0, with robust API support and enhanced performance features. It allows developers to pull data from Contentful into Markdown or YAML files for Hugo using the contentful-hugo CLI tool.

Sanity.io is a flexible headless CMS that offers real-time previews and collaboration features, making it ideal for teams that require seamless content editing and previewing. As of 2026, Sanity.io's latest version is 3.19.0, with enhanced real-time editing and AI-powered content agent features.

## Jekyll Plugin Architecture

Jekyll has a plugin system with hooks that allow you to create custom generated content specific to your site. You can run custom code for your site without having to modify the Jekyll source itself.

You can create a generator when you need Jekyll to create additional content based on your own rules. A generator is a subclass of Jekyll::Generator that defines a generate method, which receives an instance of Jekyll::Site.

## API-Driven Features in Static Sites

Today's major static site generators all include the ability to generate content from JSON data files. They also provide functions you can use to fetch content from an API and use with this feature. Hugo (my static site generator of choice) provides the getJSON function. Jekyll has a third-party plugin, jekyll_get.

I've completed the web search for "migrating custom HTML CSS to framework VitePress Astro 2026". Here's what I found:

## Key Migration Resources

Astro provides official migration tips for converting existing VuePress projects to Astro, though the search results also included guidance on VuePress-to-VitePress migrations.

## VitePress-Specific Migration Guidance

For migrating to VitePress from VuePress, the process involves several steps:

- Move CSS files, noting that VitePress will automatically discover them
- Move components from .vuepress to .vitepress directory
- Port SCSS to CSS, and rename files to use the .css extension

## Astro Migration Considerations

Astro doesn't build .astro files and instead injects default CSS files from frameworks into the <head>, which loads CSS via request once without HMR capability.

When migrating to Astro, considerations include:
- Support for UI framework components, CSS stylesheets/libraries including Tailwind, and Markdown/MDX files with existing plugins
- Quick migration using Starlight theme, though you'll lose Vue-specific features and gain multi-framework support

## Framework Comparison

VitePress achieves impressive performance through Vite's asynchronous loading of chunks and automatic CSS extraction into separate files.

input_full.command:
gh issue comment 210 --body "$(cat <<'EOF'
## Investigation Complete

### Current State
- Runway (Lean code) generates raw HTML/CSS for SBS sites
- Custom SubVerso syntax highlighting (O(1) indexed lookups)
- Interactive D3.js dependency graphs
- Full control over structure and styling

### Critical Constraints
1. **Must support Lean code rendering** with SubVerso highlighting
2. **Must embed interactive D3.js graphs** seamlessly
3. **Must be drivable from Lean programmatically** (not markdown-first)
4. **Must preserve current visual fidelity** and features

---

### Framework Categories Evaluated

#### 1. Documentation Frameworks

**Docusaurus** (https://docusaurus.io/docs/markdown-features/code-blocks):
- React-based, Prism syntax highlighting (300+ languages)
- Custom highlighting via theme swizzling
- Strong plugin ecosystem
- **Fit**: Would need custom Lean grammar for Prism + D3 component wrappers
- **Challenge**: Markdown-first (Runway generates HTML, not MD)

**MkDocs + mkdocstrings** (https://squidfunk.github.io/mkdocs-material/):
- Python-native, fast iteration
- Less extensible than Sphinx but simpler
- **Fit**: Python integration good for build scripts
- **Challenge**: Still markdown-centric, would lose Lean generation

**Sphinx** (https://satisfyhost.com/blog/best-software-documentation-tools-open-source/):
- Robust extensibility, multiple output formats
- Supports reStructuredText or Markdown
- **Fit**: Highly customizable for technical docs
- **Challenge**: Heavy, complex plugin architecture

#### 2. Academic/Mathematical Frameworks

**PreTeXt** (https://pretextbook.org/doc/guide/pretext-guide.pdf):
- XML source, multiple outputs (HTML, PDF, ePUB, Braille)
- Built for mathematical textbooks
- Uses MathJax for LaTeX equations
- **Fit**: Designed for our domain (math proofs)
- **Challenge**: XML-based (not Lean-native), would need custom conversion

**Quarto** (https://quarto.org/):
- General-purpose technical publishing
- Excellent LaTeX support, Pandoc markdown
- **Fit**: Strong math support, multiple outputs
- **Challenge**: Markdown-first, doesn't integrate with Lean code generation

#### 3. Static Site Generators

**Hugo** (https://dasroot.net/posts/2026/01/hugo-headless-cms-best-combinations-technical-blogs/):
- Fast build times, `getJSON` function for API-driven content
- Can pull from headless CMS (Contentful, Sanity)
- **Fit**: Could consume JSON from Lean, fast builds
- **Challenge**: Go templates unfamiliar, still needs content transformation layer

**Jekyll** (https://jekyllrb.com/docs/plugins/generators/):
- Ruby-based, custom generators via plugins
- `jekyll_get` plugin for API data
- **Fit**: Plugin system allows custom content generation
- **Challenge**: Ruby ecosystem, slower than Hugo

#### 4. Modern Framework-Based Generators

**VitePress** (https://olets.dev/posts/migrate-from-vuepress-to-vitepress/):
- Vue-based, Vite build system (fast)
- Async chunk loading, automatic CSS extraction
- **Fit**: Modern, fast, Vue component ecosystem for D3
- **Challenge**: Still markdown-centric, would need custom content pipeline

**Astro** (https://docs.astro.build/en/guides/migrate-to-astro/):
- Multi-framework support (React, Vue, Svelte)
- Island architecture (partial hydration)
- MDX support with custom plugins
- **Fit**: Very flexible, could embed D3 components easily
- **Challenge**: Would need to transform Runway output to Astro components

**SvelteKit** (https://medium.com/@vignarajj/sveltekit-vs-react-vue-angular-and-other-front-end-frameworks-why-sveltekit-stands-out-cfa19ce704fe):
- Compiler-driven optimization, lean output
- 2.0 release in late 2024
- **Fit**: Performance-focused, good for interactive graphs
- **Challenge**: Newer ecosystem, less documentation tooling

#### 5. Lean Ecosystem Tools

**doc-gen4** (https://github.com/leanprover/doc-gen4):
- Official Lean 4 documentation generator
- Generates HTML from Lean code
- Used for mathlib4 docs (https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/)
- **Fit**: Native Lean integration, already understands Lean syntax
- **Challenge**: Generic API docs, not designed for theorem/proof narratives

---

### Evaluation Matrix

| Framework | Lean Integration | Syntax Highlighting | D3.js Support | Programmatic Generation | Migration Effort |
|-----------|------------------|---------------------|---------------|------------------------|------------------|
| **Docusaurus** | Custom | Prism (extensible) | React components | Medium | High |
| **MkDocs** | Custom | Pygments | Plugin/JS | Medium | High |
| **Sphinx** | Custom | Pygments | Extensions | High | Very High |
| **PreTeXt** | None | MathJax only | Custom | Low | Very High |
| **Quarto** | None | Pandoc | Embedded | Low | Very High |
| **Hugo** | JSON API | Chroma | Shortcodes/JS | High | Medium-High |
| **Jekyll** | Generators | Rouge | Liquid/JS | High | Medium-High |
| **VitePress** | Custom | Shiki | Vue components | Medium | Medium |
| **Astro** | Custom | Shiki | Island components | High | Medium |
| **SvelteKit** | Custom | Custom | Svelte components | High | High |
| **doc-gen4** | Native | Native | Custom | Very High | Low (extend existing) |

---

### Key Findings

#### What Works Well Currently
- **Full control**: Custom HTML/CSS means no framework constraints
- **SubVerso integration**: O(1) indexed highlighting is fast and precise
- **Runway architecture**: Lean generates exactly what we need
- **No markdown layer**: Direct Lean → HTML removes transformation step

#### Framework Advantages
- **Component reusability**: Modern frameworks have mature component ecosystems
- **Tooling**: Hot reload, DevTools, TypeScript support
- **Community**: Larger user base, more examples/plugins
- **Standards**: Following conventions makes onboarding easier

#### Framework Disadvantages
- **Migration cost**: Porting all Runway HTML generation is substantial work
- **Abstraction overhead**: Framework layers between Lean and output
- **SubVerso preservation**: Would need to reimplement or bridge highlighting
- **Reduced control**: Framework opinions may conflict with our needs

---

### Recommendations

#### Option 1: Stay with Custom HTML/CSS + Incremental Improvements (Recommended)

**Rationale**: Current approach works and gives maximum flexibility. Address #209 friction points without framework migration.

**Improvements to consider**:
- Better CSS organization (design tokens, variables)
- Component-like patterns in Runway (reusable HTML generators)
- Visual regression testing (Percy, SnapAndCompare)
- Playwright CSS hot-swap for iteration

**Pros**:
- Low risk, incremental progress
- Preserves SubVerso and Lean integration
- No migration downtime

**Cons**:
- Still custom (less community support)
- Tooling gaps remain

#### Option 2: Hybrid Approach - Astro as Wrapper

**Rationale**: Astro's island architecture could wrap existing Runway HTML without full rewrite.

**Approach**:
- Runway generates HTML fragments
- Astro assembles fragments into pages
- Interactive components (D3) as Astro islands
- Gradual migration component-by-component

**Pros**:
- Modern tooling (Vite, hot reload)
- Preserve existing HTML generation
- Incremental migration path

**Cons**:
- New build layer adds complexity
- Still need to learn/maintain Astro
- May not solve core #209 issues

#### Option 3: Extend doc-gen4 Architecture

**Rationale**: Build on Lean ecosystem tooling instead of general-purpose frameworks.

**Approach**:
- Study doc-gen4 architecture
- Add blueprint/narrative features
- Contribute upstream or fork for SBS needs
- Leverage Lean community work

**Pros**:
- Native Lean integration
- Community alignment
- May benefit other Lean users

**Cons**:
- doc-gen4 is API-doc focused, not narrative
- Small developer community
- Still need custom work

#### Option 4: Framework Migration (Not Recommended Currently)

**Rationale**: Full migration to Docusaurus/VitePress/etc.

**Why not now**:
- High cost (weeks of work)
- Uncertain benefits for #209 friction
- Risks breaking SubVerso highlighting
- Loses Lean-native generation advantage

**When to reconsider**:
- If custom HTML becomes unmaintainable
- If we need features only frameworks provide
- If Runway complexity outgrows benefits
- If community moves to standard tooling

---

### Concrete Next Steps

1. **Solve #209 first** - Address design communication friction with current stack
2. **Prototype Astro wrapper** - Test if hybrid approach adds value without full rewrite
3. **Study doc-gen4** - Understand if extending Lean ecosystem tools is viable
4. **Defer full migration** - Only consider if incremental improvements fail

The current custom approach is defensible and may be optimal for our specific constraints (Lean-driven generation, SubVerso highlighting, D3 graphs). Framework adoption should be need-driven, not cargo-culting.

---

**Research Sources**:
- Docusaurus: https://docusaurus.io/docs/markdown-features/code-blocks
- Sphinx: https://satisfyhost.com/blog/best-software-documentation-tools-open-source/
- PreTeXt: https://pretextbook.org/doc/guide/pretext-guide.pdf
- Quarto: https://quarto.org/
- Hugo headless CMS: https://dasroot.net/posts/2026/01/hugo-headless-cms-best-combinations-technical-blogs/
- Jekyll plugins: https://jekyllrb.com/docs/plugins/generators/
- VitePress migration: https://olets.dev/posts/migrate-from-vuepress-to-vitepress/
- Astro migration: https://docs.astro.build/en/guides/migrate-to-astro/
- doc-gen4: https://github.com/leanprover/doc-gen4
- mathlib4 docs: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/
- Framework comparison 2026: https://www.nucamp.co/blog/javascript-framework-trends-in-2026-what-s-new-in-react-next.js-vue-angular-and-svelte
EOF
)"
